{"comments": {"id": 509, "count": 121, "talk_id": 623}, "threadId": 509, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "623", "description": "Josh Silver delivers his brilliantly simple solution for correcting vision at the lowest cost possible -- adjustable, liquid-filled lenses. At TEDGlobal 2009, he demos his affordable eyeglasses and reveals his global plan to distribute them to a billion people in need by 2020.", "event": "TEDGlobal 2009", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Joshua Silver: Adjustable liquid-filled eyeglasses", "slug": "josh_silver_demos_adjustable_liquid_filled_eyeglasses", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "494", "slug": "joshua_silver", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Joshua", "lastname": "Silver", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Optical innovator", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/112542_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Atomic physicist Joshua Silver invented liquid-filled optical lenses to produce low-cost, adjustable glasses, giving sight to millions without access to an optometrist.", "whylisten": "

Joshua Silver reckons that around half the world's population needs corrective eyewear, yet has no access to it. His ultra-utilitarian spectacle design relies on the principle that the fatter the lens, the more powerful it becomes. The lenses are filled with liquid, and can be adjusted to different strengths by adding or removing fluid from tiny syringes on each arm, then locked to the right strength.

More than 30,000 of his lenses have been distributed in 15 countries, and a new model will scale that number up to millions.

author: Joshua_Silver;
title: Adjustable liquid-filled eyeglasses

aws-transcripts.transcript: I'm going to tell you about one of the world's largest problems on how it can be solved. I'd like to start with a little experiment. Could you put your hand up if you wear glasses or contact lenses or you've had laser refractive surgery? Now, unfortunately, there are too many off you for me to do the statistics properly, but it looks like I'm guessing that it will be about 60% of the room because that's roughly the fraction off a developed world population that have some sort of vision correction, the World Health Organization estimates, where they make various estimates of the number of people that need glasses, the lowest estimate is 100 and 50,000,000 people. They also have an estimate of around 1,000,000,000. But in fact I would argue that we've just done an experiment here and now, which shows us that the global need for corrective eyewear is around half of any population, and the problem of poor vision is actually not just a health problem. It's also an educational problem, and it's an economic problem, and it's a quality of life problems. Glasses are not very expensive, they're quite plentiful. The problem is that there aren't enough eye care professionals in the world to use the model of the delivery off corrective eyewear that we have in the developed world. We're just waiting few eye care professionals. So this little slide here shows you on optometrist and the little blue person represents about 10,000 people. And that's the ratio in the UK. This is the ratio of optometrists to people in sub Saharan Africa. In fact, there are some countries in sub Saharan Africa where this one optometrist for 8,000,000 of the population how do you do this? How do you solve this problem? I came up with a solution to this problem, and I came up with a solution based on adaptive optics for this. And the idea is you make eyeglasses and you adjust them yourself, and that solves the problem. What I want to do is to show you that one can make a pair of glasses and I should just I should just show you how you make a pair of glasses. I should pop the this in my pocket. I'm short sighted.
